comments.commentBody: It was grotewque listening to her manipulate the factions to her political benefit.

The fact that it took the murders of nine African Americans for South Carolina and the nation to confront the leprous legacy of the Confederacy,their nefarious 'flags and its continuing stain on American body politic,has finally been realized,after the last doomed episode of 'Pickett's Charge at Gettysburg.The South claimed to be a sovereign nation,who were at war with the legitimate sovereign nation of the United States of America.The rebels lost...Hence,a losing nation does fly their emblem ANYWHERE,in the land of the victorious nation.This is particularly true,when a controversially defiant nature is subversively attached so this co-called 'battle flag.If South Carolina desires to secede...again,a'majority SCOTUS opinion,is a 'possibility.'Considering.

Let's get real here:  Mossad is a greater threat to the stability of the American polis, which it isn't, than a bunch of guys driving around waving the Confederate Flag.  That is to say, the real issue is about the center controlling the freedom of speech--its greatest threat--and waving the bloody shirt, i.e., the flag, is just a means for the center to continue stomping, the way the political class maintains its control of the center.

I must strongly disagree with your statement that it wasn't racism that killed the victims of this massacre. It most certainly was a person with racial animus that took the lives of others. Please quit trying to equate mental illness with racism. His statements specifically say that he was looking to kill African-Americans.

Additionally, please quit trying to justify the carrying of guns as a way of protecting oneself. The victims were killed in a house of worship. One shouldn't need to carry guns in those places.

Ancestors affiliated with buying, selling or trafficking of other human beings should not be memorialized in a way that portrays them in positive light. If they died trying to preserve one of the worst aspects of humanity then shame on them. Time won't change the facts.
Is there a happy face in this picture?

Time to exercise a little political speech and BURN the Confederate Battle Flag, often and in public.

Thank the US Supreme Court for opining that flag burning is protected political speech. Oh, yeah ... Not THIS Supreme Court. Go back to the 1990's.

Michelle, for someone who suggests that others are ignorant and should read more, you have a lot of misspellings and grammatical errors in your post.  You can respectfully disagree without suggesting that those who are offended by the flag have lost their minds.  South Carolina is rich with history; why hold onto a symbol that for many represents a very dark stain on that past.
Fly your flag proudly Michele.  Just remember it is the flag of traitors who lost.  By the way, the South's beliefs included the right to "own" other people.  Deal with it!
The real issue is racism.

In reply to Tomas Macias, Arizona

"No one in their sane mind could justify killing the most innocent and defenseless among us" This statement expresses an irrational wish rather than hard facts.

Most killings in US is done by people who are NOT mentally ill.

Race based killings, even if sugar-coated to hide them behind mental illness, reflect the sentiments of the society in which these individuals live.

Would bona fide racists accept a label of being called "racist" or "mentally ill"? They are "crazy" enough to be racist but they would chose "mentally ill" label over the other.

People who knew Mr Roof knew his racist views. How did they react?
Did they agree with him?
Did they take pride in him taking pride of the flag?
did they think he was mentally ill and bring him to a psychiatrist for treatment of "racism"?
Does racism become mental illness ONLY when the person shoots someone?
At what stage of racism does it become a mental illness such that guns should be denied to them?
Are we going to dilute the issue of racism by complicating the discussion with gun rights?
why are we afraid to call a spade a spade?
Why do we believe we know the answers to important questions instead of asking more important incisive questions?

Well isn't this the Pity Party!!

Sorry, but believing in your own made up history does not make it "History", it makes it stuff you like to believe. Take your own good advice and read some real history, not the comic book version you just presented: "the north wanted us to do things their way". That is some weak tea there, sister.

And no, if you provide offensive ignorance under the headline "my heritage" and think that is off limits to questions, real history, facts, then you will always have a victim narrative. The South is much greater than this grievance mentality stoked by radio host airheads and people who need a club to belong to.

Governor Haley made the right decision.  It remains to be seen whether the South Carolina legislature will follow suit.  If they choose inaction, the collective national business community should simply boycott South Carolina businesses or place restrictions on travel to South Carolina until this vestige of hatred is removed.  Such pressure worked recently in Indiana and Arkansas with their misguided recent "religious freedom" laws.  The same pressure will assuredly work in South Carolina as well.
This flag should have been taken down 150 years ago. There is no reason to debate that anymore. It needs to come down immediately and the south needs to move into the 21st century.
I heard on NPR that the flag went up in SC after desegregation-- not 150 years ago.  If this is true, it is even MORE shocking that it has been allowed.

I do not know the entire history behind the Confederate flag but I have regarded the flying of the Confederate flag by SC as an affront to equal rights and those who believe in it. However, I would urge the politicians not to take a decision while emotions are running high. While I believe this is the right decision, I believe this should be debated/decided 6 or 8 weeks from now when the emotions are not so high.

I am concerned that if decisions are taken in the "heat of the moment", then it sets a bad example. There is going to be a nut (most likely on Fox News) that is going to make the argument that if SC could take down a flag because of the massacre that happened there, then why shouldn't NY close down its mosques because of massacres that happened there.

The means are as important as the end...

Let's see what the Confederate flag(s) meant to those who actually designed them.

The first official CSA flag was the "Stars and Bars", which is *not* the "Battle Flag" at issue here. It was universally hated because it closely resembled the "Yankee" flag that stood for "abolitionist despotism".

It was replaced with the "Stainless Banner" by William T Thompson. He put the now-familiar "Battle flag" in the upper corner of a white background and called it the "White Man's Flag". Here's what he said about it:

"As a people we are fighting to maintain the Heaven-ordained supremacy of the white man over the inferior or colored race; a white flag would thus be emblematical of our cause."
Wow, I feel like Rip Van Winkle just walked through the room. You are writing these questions from South Africa? Again, Wow.

Oh, I don't have any problem with displaying either the Confederate Battle Flag or the German flag of 1933-1945 on public property. Or the Imperial Japanese "rising sun" flag or the flag of the USSR for that matter.

As long as the public property in question is inside a museum.
we all need to consider how much the Civil war in the States was never a completed issue

Ms. McCullough, have you lost your mind?
"The north always trying to force what they want down the southerners throats just like they did during the civil war." The Civil War was to preserve the Union and end slavery. I'm glad we forced those things down your throat.

"The confederate flag represents the south and the way of life," an agricultural economy that needed slavery to survive. Yes, your way of life was built on the blacks of slaves.

"I'm proud to fly the confederate flag,it is my heritage if it offends people then so be it,that shows ignorance on the ones that get offended." I am a HUGE free speech advocate and as I tell my middle school students, we owe a huge debt of gratitude to ignorant people when they speak up and let themselves be known. Prejudice, bigotry, discrimination, anti-semitism, and homophobia are much easier to identify and dismantle when they are know. Please, continue to fly your flag. And thank you.
As a general rule, the best writing in a newspaper is in the sports section.

Great, great sports writing. It's been awhile since I've read something this intelligent when it comes to sports. (Of course, I must admit I don't read a lot of sports, but nonetheless, this is great writing.)

Dear Enemy of Crime,
Thanks, I had a feeling it was something like that. I'd bet it's even a better betting game, not getting skewed by bad calls and so on.

Dear AK,
Sorry about the tone; I did mean to bash FIFA for their scandalous actions, and I do care that we do well in an international competition like this. I also meant to scold Men's fans for their lack of attention. Personally, weirdly, I get really enthusiastic at every sport I attend, but on TV it loses my interest, so I'm not a good promoter of enthusiasm generally. Anyway no hard feelings and hope that's more clear, cheers!
I agree. But let's hope not. May be luck with be with US team again, like in Columbia game and US will win.

You never know, china doesn't have as much speed as some other opponents and US may be more willing to play higher up not worried about the counter so much and if US plays some quicker players than Abby (who really is a designated set piece hitter in there) US can make some things happen. I will say another shutout and go crazy with a 3-0 prediction.

Don't underestimate the ability of the US women to rise to the occasion. Alex Morgan is just polishing off the rust. She is still fast and deceptive with her moves, has excellent ball control and is lethal with her shot from either foot, both in close and from distance.

The coach needs to start some fast fresh legs out there from the younger players to wear China down with speed and then sub some veterans as needed. Wambach should sit on the bench until a critical moment in the second half. She collided with Lloyd as they were both going for a header. It's not like this is their first rodeo.

I predict China PR will beat USA in the WWC quarter-finals on Friday June 26 with Rapinoe and Holiday out of the lineup. I've seen China play live twice in this tournament. Here's why I think they'll win: (1) they have two extra days rest, having played their quarter-final game on Saturday June 20; (2) they are outstanding defensively. I don't think the US will score a single goal; (3) China is highly disciplined, as befits their political structure. They will never be playing 10 against 11 as Colombia had to. USA's only chance is their great defense.

Well done.  Thanks for the analysis.  I actually didn't watch the match but through every tournament, whether the World Cup, Gold Cup or whatever, that rule irritates me to no end.  But you are right, they knew the rules and knew what the consequences would have been if they were playing reckless and / or whining.
Maybe we should issue headgear and pads too?

Yellow card accumulation and the threat of missing the next game keeps players from committing foolish challenges. It will make you think twice about committing a "professional foul". There is a time and place for it but it can work against you with suspension.

The yellow card accumulation leading to suspension is just another ridiculous archaic rule that needs to revised or done away with completely. So 2 cards, given out subjectively we should add, over the course of four games leads to players missing out on a quarter-final of the World Cup? Absolutely ridiculous.

It was a blatant trip. As a parent of a college player (GK), I know most people haven't a clue about the laws of the game, but my kid has been ejected for the same thing. It was an easy call for the ref.

The first half was even if anything with Columbia outplaying the US much of the time on possession and stringing passes together, which the US women usually do with great finesse. I think Columbia got disheartened when their keeper was booted and eventually were worn down by the constant US attacks so they had nothing left in the tank but to commit egregious fouls.

@ Paul — Boy, I’ve looked at the replay of Rapinoe’s pass and Morgan’s run, ending in the red-card foul — see:

http://tinyurl.com/nd2ddty

starting at 0:55 — and I just don’t see that, “[h]ad Perez not hesitated to advance, she would have easily beaten Morgan to the ball and cleared the danger.”

Both players are first in the frame about 0:58, with the ball at least a dozen yards above the top of the penalty area, Morgan is maybe 6 or 7 yards from the ball; Perez is at least 15 yards from it. (Yes, Morgan is chasing the ball, which is heading toward Perez, but Morgan is already at full gallop, and Perez needs to accelerate from a standing start.)

Perez does hesitate after taking a couple or three steps, pausing about level with the penalty spot, at 0:59. That probably was not the best reaction, but at that point Morgan was about two strides from the ball, and Perez was still about 10 yards from it.

When Morgan reaches the ball, it’s at about level with the top of the arc. Given Morgan’s running start, I don’t think Perez could have beaten her to the ball — and it would have been a heck of a risk, charging out beyond the area on such a close challenge against one of the game’s fastest and most dangerous strikers.

Can I say Perez •couldn’t• have beaten Morgan to the ball? Not absolutely, though I don’t think she would have. But as to your contention that Perez could have “easily beaten” her to it — with all respect, the visual evidence simply doesn’t support that.

— Brian

For sheer drama this game could not be beat. Imagine a gutsy and young goalie showing her mettle, until what I considered an unnecessary red card in the penalty area caused her ejection from the game. The cameras zoomed in on her face, a portrait of shock and disbelief. With unbelievable grace, she walks off without complaint. Then, the replacement goalie steps in, under impossible pressure, to face Wambach in a penalty kick - one of the best women's soccer players in the world.The new goalie had virtually no chance of stopping the kick, but the master kicker of women's soccer did not even kick the ball within the goal boundaries. Unbelievable!
Finally, the US ground the Colombians to defeat through better organizational, if not athletic skills.

"The difference in comfort on the ball in tight spaces between the Colombians and the Americans was both startling and disturbing. Even though they produced nothing like an end product, watching the Colombians play with flair (more Brazilian flair than the Brazilians managed against Australia), panache and no fear was a lot more impressive than watching Lloyd, Holiday, Heath and Rapinoe spray balls to either team.
It's a win, but as unimpressive one as I can remember for the USWNT in ANY previous WWC."

That about sums it up. Startling and disturbing.
